songs.title: Ill Wind

description.plain:
“Ill Wind” was released as a bonus track on Radiohead’s special edition of A Moon Shaped Pool, and later on streaming services. In 2016, Stereogum described it as having “an almost bossanova-esque groove that eventually transitions into an icy synth exercise.”

Thom Yorke said he had been working on the track since as early as 2008, under the working title “The North Wind.”

Although not directly related, the song shares its title with a classic jazz standard from the 1930s, performed by Ella Fitzgerald, Frank Sinatra, Debbie Harry, and many others.

songs.title: Sulk

description.plain:
“Sulk” was written as a response to the Hungerford massacre that occurred in Hungerford, Berkshire, England on August 19, 1987. Seventeen people (including the perpetrator) were killed in the massacre.

Although its original concluding lyrics were “just shoot your gun,” these were changed when the song was recorded in late 1994. This was because the death of Kurt Cobain was still weighing heavily on people’s minds while the Hungerford killings were not; Thom chose to change the lyrics so that no one would think the song was about the late Nirvana leader.

“Sulk” is rarely heard live: the band played it in concert a few times in 1994 and 1995, and never again after that.

songs.title: Go to Sleep

description.plain:
The fifth track begins with an acoustic guitar riff Colin Greenwood described as “1960s English sort of folk”. Yorke wrote the lyrics as placeholders with the intent of rewriting them later, but kept them as he had not rewritten them by the day of recording.

He later realised they were “really amazing” and the lyrics he was most proud of on the album. The line

May pretty horses / come to you / as you sleep"

May derive from “All the Pretty Horses,” a common lullaby.

Alternative Title: “Go to Sleep (Little Man Being Erased)”

songs.title: Scatterbrain

description.plain:
Here’s what Thom said about it:

It’s a really, really difficult song to describe. My favourite type of weather in the whole wide world is extreme winds. It is a bit dangerous. I have a house in the middle of nowhere and the house next door, the roof blew up and we just watched it and it was exactly like ‘The Wizard of Oz’. It was fantastic. And this was a similar incident in the city. But it’s kind of a love song as well, in a way.

Alternative Title: “Scatterbrain (As Dead as Leaves)”

songs.title: Dollars and Cents

description.plain:
“Dollars and Cents”, whose lyrical content is strikingly similar to the anti-government, anti-corporate themes expressed on their 1997 classic, OK Computer. Ed O'Brien’s minimal, warped guitarwork and Jonny Greenwood’s distant string arrangements float celestially over brother Colin’s menacing basslines and Selway’s delicate drumming.

The song originally came out of an 11 minute improvisation session by the band, editing down the best parts and featuring a one-take vocal performance from Thom Yorke, who states of the song that his lyrics were “gibberish” – “Lyrically, I like doing things like that…it was about being in the moment”. The song’s lyrics have been widely debated by fans and change up frequently at live shows, obfuscated in the mix by Yorke’s mumbling and layered riffing over the track.

songs.title: Treefingers

description.plain:
“Treefingers” is Kid A’s 5th track, and the first instrumental track to feature in a Radiohead LP. This song acts as an interlude between “How to Disappear Completely”, a song centered around loneliness, and “Optimistic”, a song that serves to critique society’s consumerism. This track illustrates Colin Greenwood’s desire to make an album that was neither too long nor too boring, according to SongFacts.

The track was used in Christopher Nolan’s Memento, as part of the soundtrack for the movie.

songs.title: The Gloaming

description.plain:
‘The Gloaming’ was born when Radiohead recorded Kid A during the experimental electronica-only sessions in early 2000, when the band split into teams who worked on different things seperately. Colin and Jonny created an instrumental track, that would serve Thom much later as the basis for working out a melody. A version called ‘33.3 Recurring’, that most likely represents the state of work from the Kid A sessions, appeared on an EMI acetate disc in 2003, suggesting it was considered for b-side release. (Source).

Thom Yorke said before performing this song:

The next song we’re gonna do is a song about the rise of fascism and the right wing. The only way to stop them is to do something. If you do nothing, they’ll win. And these people are fucking crazy.

Alternative Title: “The Gloaming (Softly Open our Mouths in the Cold)”

songs.full_title: Anyone Can Play Guitar by Radiohead
songs.title: Anyone Can Play Guitar

description.plain:
“Anyone Can Play Guitar” is a single from Radiohead’s first album Pablo Honey, released just in advance of the album. It is the band’s second single, and their first to receive a wide hearing. “Anyone Can Play Guitar” made relatively little impression on the charts, but it remained a staple of the band’s live sets throughout the early-mid 1990s.

In this song Yorke heaps scorn on desperate wannabes who seek validation via rock stardom.

songs.title: Backdrifts

description.plain:
The fourth track is an electronic song built from a loop Yorke created on a portable Walkstation synthesiser before the Kid A and Amnesiac sessions.

Bassist Colin Greenwood called the track the point when we managed to work out how to make all the boxes and machines talk to each other.

The lyrical imagery came from the time the band became trapped on a bullet train in a snowdrift in Japan:

The snow was piled high on the branches, and then a bullet train would go past, and the snow would drop off the branch. The whole world was utterly blanketed except for these straggly bits of black and white. And that’s where it started. The words have always been based in that image.“He described the song as being about "the slide backwards that’s happening everywhere you look.”

Alternative Title: “Backdrifts (Honeymoon is Over)”

songs.full_title: How I Made My Millions by Radiohead
songs.title: How I Made My Millions

description.plain:
“How I Made My Millions” was released in 1998 on the No Surprises single. It can also be found on the Collector’s Edition of OK Computer, as well as on the second disc of OK Computer OKNOTOK 1997 2017.

This song provides a unique insight into the band’s songwriting process. Using his personal four-track recorder, Thom performed this song at home, intending it to be a demo for the rest of the band members to use to begin developing a full arrangement.

Upon hearing the recording, the rest of the band decided that it was fine just the way it was, with Ed and Phil saying that it “blew them away.” Despite the conspicuous noise of Thom’s partner cleaning up their home in the background, the band decided to release it as-is.

We can speculate for days about the particular qualities of this recording  that inspired Radiohead, a band now notorious for working on songs for years (“Nude” – written 1996, released 2007; “Morning Mr. Magpie” – written 2002, released 2011) to simply release it without further effort.

Exclusively considering the lyrics, it is hard to extrapolate a meaning. It is unclear whether the narrator of the song is the owner of the “millions” suggested by the title, or if this “millionaire” is the subject who was “picked out."Both possibilities suggest significantly different meanings.

Of course, it is certainly within the realm of possibility that the relationship on display in the song, one of user and used, is entirely the point, and that Thom’s intention is to offer a basic illustration of exploitation as a statement against capitalism. (To be clear, while I see a case being made for this interpretation, I am not necessarily advocating for it.)

Ultimately, the repetition of the line “Let it Fall” near the end of the song offers a degree of closure, as if the narrator is encouraging us to “let it go,” to resign ourselves to let whatever is going to happen happen. And of course, there’s nothing contained in the preceding lyrics to offer any support to this interpretation. Instead, I am arriving at this understanding based on the feeling Thom seems to communicate as he sings these lines. Indeed, my experience with Radiohead has often been that the emotional content of their music is far more powerful to me than any intellectual meaning one can read into it.

songs.title: 4 Minute Warning

description.plain:
Thom has said that In Rainbows is “about the fucking panic of realizing you’re going to die!” Keeping with that theme, “4 Minute Warning” describes a vague apocalyptic scenario that the narrator is trapped in the middle of.

The four-minute warning was a public alert system conceived by the British Government during the Cold War and operated between 1953 and 1992. The name derived from the approximate length of time from the point at which a Soviet nuclear missile attack against the United Kingdom could be confirmed and the impact of those missiles on their targets. The population was to be notified by means of air raid sirens, television and radio, and urged to seek cover immediately.

songs.title: Hunting Bears

description.plain:
“Hunting Bears” is a two-minute instrumental song, the third purely instrumental piece on Radiohead’s catalogue (after “Treefingers” and “Meeting in the Aisle”), and the only one focused on guitars.

The slide guitar is reminiscent of Ry Cooder’s work and of Neil Young’s Dead Man soundtrack.

Instead of, as a band would usually do, using a short instrumental piece as a segue into a related piece of music, “Hunting Bears” links two songs completely dissimilar with it and between each other: “Dollars and Cents” and “Like Spinning Plates”.



Considering that “Hunting Bears” was written during the Kid A sessions, the track may be related to the “Modified Bear” logo used when advertising that album. Perhaps also a shout out to Björk, with whom Thom has worked.

songs.full_title: Harry Patch (In Memory Of) by Radiohead
songs.title: Harry Patch (In Memory Of)

description.plain:
This 2009 self-released non-album single was released after the death of Harry Patch, who up until his death, was the last surviving combat soldier to have served in World War I. The song was written in 2005, after Thom Yorke was inspired by a “very emotional” interview with Patch that aired on BBC Radio 4. Yorke wrote on an August 8th, 2005 post on the Dead Air Space blog :

The way he talked about war had a profound effect on me."

“Harry Patch (In Memory Of)” was recorded live in an abbey a few weeks before Patch passed away on July 25, 2009 at the age of 111.

The song mainly consists of a string arrangement composed and arranged by Jonny Greenwood layered underneath Yorke’s vocals, which take a drastic turn from his ususal abstract style of songwriting, instead telling the song from the perspective of a solder in trench warfare during the First World War.



Patch seen in the photo above at age 109 sitting by a lake in Prior Park Landscape Garden in Somerset, England.

The song was re-released as a single on Remembrance Day 2016 on XL Recordings, with new artwork by Stanley Donwood.

songs.title: Untitled

description.plain: The final track of Radiohead’s 4th LP is a haunting, ambient untitled bonus track. On the original pressing of the album, the song plays after a minute of silence after the conclusion of the final track “Motion Picture Soundtrack”, and is followed by another minute of silence. On some digital releases, it is listed as its own track, and the silence is omitted.

songs.title: Follow Me Around

description.plain:
After the release of some previously unreleased material in OKNOTOK, this is now probably the oldest and best known “lost song” by Radiohead.

It is known that the band attempted to record it in both the OK Computer and in the Kid A/Amnesiac sessions, but wasn’t satisfied with the results. The first (and to date only) “official” recording of the song was in the documentary “Meeting People is Easy” from 1998, showing the band playing it in a soundcheck in Fukuoka, Japan.
https://youtu.be/POmiH-DvJ1U

It was properly debuted, after fan request, at a performance in Toronto, in 2000, from which the lyrics in the left were lifted. After that, it was played live in 10 other occasions: once more in 2000, twice in 2001, once in 2002, twice in 2003, once in 2006 (as an intro to “Everything in Its Right Place”), once in 2009 (Tom Solo), once in 2010 (with Atoms for Peace) and finally once in 2017, this time losing its “acoustic” properties.
https://youtu.be/2FchhX4hdo8

As can be seen here the band has also posted different portions of the lyrics in their website, linking it to other songs such as “Kid A” and “Where I End and You Begin”. Some of the lyrics also feature on the hidden booklet in Kid A:

songs.embed_content: Read “Follow Me Around” by Radiohead on Genius

songs.title: How Do You?

description.plain: This track from Pablo Honey differs from the others; whereas most of the album falls under alternative rock and post-grunge, this track is very grunge styling, and Thom’s voice is exaggerated to fit this description. Upon the album’s release, critics hated on this song. As critics over at NME put it, the track “breaks the momentum of Pablo Honey horribly, throwing all of Radiohead’s tortured sensitivity out of the window and leaving them sounding like beer-gutted losers from the class of ‘76”. Nonetheless, it remained a staple at live shows throughout the Pablo Honey tour, although it has been all but ditched from live shows in recent years.

songs.title: Palo Alto

description.plain:
Palo Alto, California is the home of Stanford University and a major center of the Silicon Valley. When Radiohead performed in the city in 1996, they toured the offices of several prominent technology companies.



Pictured: A rendering of Apple Park, located in nearby Cupertino.

The original title of the song was “OK Computer”, meaning this song continues with the prominent techno-paranoia, personal dettachment, and anti-corporate themes in the eponymous album, applying them to what’s regarded as the world’s foremost innovation hub: Silicon Valley. It captures the other prominent theme of alienation that the English narrator feels. The specificity of this song is odd considering how general if not vague the rest of OK Computer is, which might explain why it became a B-side. Palo Alto really works as an archetype for the issues Radiohead is dealing with in the album.

“Palo Alto” was released in 1997 on the “No Surprises” single. It can also be found on the Airbag/How Am I Driving EP, on the Collector’s Edition of OK Computer and on disk 2 of the 20th anniversary edition, OKNOTOK.

songs.title: I Can’t

description.plain: “I Can’t” is the tenth song on Radiohead’s debut album, Pablo Honey. The song has a theme of low self-esteem which is also followed up on the next song in the album, “Lurgee”. Both songs feature a theme of doubt. While “Lurgee” doesn’t as strongly depict doubt, it has stronger themes of self-depreciation than “I Can’t,” making it a good sequel to the song.

songs.title: Lull

description.plain:
“Lull” was released in 1997 on the “Karma Police” single.



It can also be found on the Collector’s Edition of OK Computer.

A bright melody of Velvet Underground simplicity, Lull can be likened to Radiohead’s ‘No Surprises’, with an upbeat melody and yet somewhat sorrowful lyrics.

The song also features a xylophone played by Jonny Greenwood.

It’s one of several vague allusions to well-managed, strongly medicated depression… with a hint of frustration that real feelings are being locked up, as the singer shrinks to nothing: “Crawling through the keyhole… I’m in a lull”.

Radiohead has yet to play Lull live.

songs.title: Lurgee

description.plain:
Lurgee (also spelled Lurgy) is a fictitious, highly infectious disease.  There is a common enough phrase “the dreaded lurgy,” and this is a song really about dread itself, a soul sickness, a disease of modernity.

Alongside Creep, this is one of the tracks that suggested that Radiohead were more than just another alt-rock band. It’s a gorgeous, mid-paced track with clean, chiming guitars and melody that snakes its way up the scales before reaching the falsetto note.

songs.title: Melatonin

description.plain:
“Melatonin” was released in 1997 on the “Paranoid Android” single.



It can also be found on the Collector’s Edition of OK Computer.

Melatonin is a hormone that helps regulate the sleep / wake cycle.  The body’s melatonin levels increase at night, inducing drowsiness.  Some people take it as a dietary supplement to aid sleeping.

The song “Melatonin” might also be a sleep-aid as it is a lullaby.

songs.title: Supercollider

description.plain:
Originally introduced at a performance in Dublin in 2008, “Supercollider” made its way to the King of the Limbs recordings where it was mixed and recorded officially and then finally released as a single for Record Store Day in 2011.

The title and lyrics of the song are of course reminiscent of Thom Yorke’s parallel project Atoms for Peace. They did play the song twice in their 2009 sets.



The working title for the song was “Solutions”. With seven minutes and one second length, it’s the longest Radiohead track of all time.

songs.full_title: (ocean) bloom by Radiohead (Ft. BBC Concert Orchestra & Hans Zimmer)
songs.title: (ocean) bloom
songs.title_with_featured: (ocean) bloom (Ft. BBC Concert Orchestra & Hans Zimmer)

description.plain:
Radiohead joined forces with iconic film composer Hans Zimmer for the release of the follow-up to David Attenborough’s acclaimed Blue Plant documentary. The orchestral arrangement is a re-working of “Bloom” taken from 2011’s The King of Limbs.

Thom Yorke is known for his environmental activism. He revealed that the original song was inspired by Blue Planet, originally released in 2001.

“Bloom” was inspired by the original Blue Planet series so it’s great to be able to come full circle with the song and re-imagine it for this incredible landmark’s sequel.

Listen to a full audio stream (without narration) here:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xnzdcRyDg94

songs.full_title: The Amazing Sounds of Orgy by Radiohead
songs.title: The Amazing Sounds of Orgy

description.plain:
This song was recorded during the Kid A/Amnesiac sessions and released as a B-side on the Pyramid Song single in May 2001. However, it has lately been played live for the first time on the 2012 tour. Before performing the song live in 2012, Thom Yorke introduced it as “an old B-side we wrote some time ago. from when I was obsessed with the banking system.  all that bull… as you might say down here [reference to the show being in Austin, Texas]. It was gonna collapse but then nothing happened for ten years and the song disappeared like a wet fart in the wind”.

Orgy because in that time banks operated a complex monopoly (this meant enterprises colluded, and acted as if they were a single one).

songs.full_title: These Are My Twisted Words by Radiohead
songs.title: These Are My Twisted Words

description.plain:
“These Are My Twisted Words” was leaked by Radiohead themselves on Bittorrent on the 12th of August, 2009.

Although released 2 years before the following Radiohead album, The King Of Limbs, this song definitely foreshadows the way of its' production, using sequenced drums and acoustic guitar patterns.

Inside the torrent file was an .nfo file containing ASCII art, a cryptic poem and a reference to a release date of the 17th of August. It was then released as a free single on that day.



i just wanted to reassure readers
that following representations
seeking confirmation
that before your very eyes
behind the wall of ice
that the box is not under threat
however they are set to remove other boxes
in fact i have the list in front of me
i went to a briefing on their plans
and challenged them to tell me
exactly what the cost would be
they spoke in broad terms
we’re looking for: talented puppeters
worms, disgrunted executive, sacked flies
genres: doomcore folktronica, ukf

On November 11th, 2016, it was released free to stream on Spotify, along with “Harry Patch (In Memory Of)”.

songs.full_title: I Want None of This by Radiohead
songs.title: I Want None of This

description.plain:
“I Want None of This” was created for the album “Help! A Day in the Life”. The album is a compilation album produced by the UK charity War Child. It was created to raise money for charity efforts in war-torn countries.

Thom recorded this song for release alone in the studio. In June and May of 2006, this song, “I Want None of This” was performed live four times with only Thom on the piano.

songs.title: Banana Co

description.plain:
Great but often overlooked song. Radiohead first played it live in May 8th, 1992, in Glasgow, two days before the acoustic version (recorded at Signal One radio station) being first released as a B-Side to Pop is Dead. The same version also made the Itch EP the following year. Therefore, it is either a Pablo Honey out-take or an early The Bends composition.

From 1993 to 1998, it became a staple of the band’s concerts, and on 1995 a full studio version came out on the benefit album Criminal Justice: Axe the Act.  The next year it was included as a b-side on the Street Spirit (Fade Out), and it eventually also came out on The Bends collector’s edition. The last known performances of the song were in 1998.

The song has a simple structure and apparently simple lyrics, although it is deeply allegorical and inter-textual. It parallels passages from Colombian writer Gabriel García Marquez’s novel One Hundred Years of Solitude with more general (although never quite explicit) references to neoliberal, neocolonial violence and economic domination in so-called “developing countries, being, thus, an early example of the band’s commitment to political agendas such as "Drop the Debt”, “Amnesty International”, etc.



After a performance of the song in San Francisco, in 1998, Thom Yorke succinctly summed up the kind of political stance behind the lyrics:

That was for Indonesia and for people who have money invested into that country.

songs.title: The Trickster

description.plain:
The Trickster is a B-Side to My Iron Lung that seldom got played live (once in 1994 and 9 times between 1997 and 1998) and never got much attention. It is a particularly noisy song for the band with a progression reminiscent of heavy metal.

In the study of mythology and psychological archetypes used in oral or written literature, a trickster is a character that is greatly smart and cunning. They are neither good or bad, but stray from normal rules and conventional behaviour, using their skills to play tricks on other people, spirits or animals.

Famous examples include Loki from Norse mythology, Anansi from West African and Caribbean tales, and the Coyote of Native American myths.

songs.title: Cuttooth

description.plain:
Recorded during the epic sessions that would yield “Kid A” and “Amnesiac”, “Cuttooth” was originally a contender to appear on the latter until being demoted to a “Knives Out” B-Side.

Ed O'Brien described the song as having a sound reminiscent of krautrock pioneers Neu! The propulsive tempo, sprawling arrangement, and a lush, powerful vocal presence from Thom Yorke make this song an anomaly relative to the rest of the band’s output during this era.

songs.full_title: Meeting in the Aisle by Radiohead
songs.title: Meeting in the Aisle

description.plain:
Radiohead’s first ever instrumental – programmed entirely on synthesizers by Henry Binns and Sam Hardaker (those responsible for the “Climbing Up the Walls” Zero 7 remix). “It was a direction we hadn’t really explored before,” explains Ed O'Brien. “Meeting in the Aisle” was used as the entrance song (taking place of “Fitter Happier”) for the band’s 1998 shows.

“Meeting in the Aisle” made its live debut in 2012 on The King of Limbs tour alongside other B sides like “The Amazing Sounds of Orgy” from Radiohead’s back catalogue that had not previously been performed in concert.

songs.title: Pop Is Dead

description.plain:
Pop Is Dead was Radiohead’s first non-album single, released in 1993, and was the only non-album single until ‘Harry Patch (In Memory Of)’ in 2009. It was not a big success, reaching only 42 on the UK Charts.

The song is a satirical look at the way the media try to repackage everything as the new rock ‘n’ roll.

songs.title: India Rubber

description.plain:
“India Rubber” was released as a B-side to the 1995 US version of the single High and Dry and a B-side to CD1 of the single Fake Plastic Trees. The song is known for its prominent drums and the creepy laugh of Radiohead’s guitarist, Jonny Greenwood.



The lyrics deal with a love that’s fake, with the person who Thom Yorke sings for doing anything to spend time with his crush/lover, who doesn’t like him but knows that she can use him to her advantage.

songs.title: MK 1

description.plain: The title is a possible refence to MKUltra, a project directed by the CIA to study means of mind control. The track’s atmosphere aims to create the sense of discomfort that relates to the experiment.

songs.title: Cut A Hole

description.plain:
‘Cut A Hole’ is one of the many songs that Radiohead played live during their King of Limbs tour that hasn’t had an LP release. Many anticipated the song to be on Radiohead’s ninth LP release, A Moon Shaped Pool, but sadly it was absent.

The song concerns an inability to connect with a love interest and believing that if you become someone else it may change the situation.

songs.full_title: How Can You Be Sure? by Radiohead
songs.title: How Can You Be Sure?

description.plain:
One of the songs demoed by the band in a couple of tapes from 1990, when they were still called On a Friday, it was later reworked and released as a B-side from the time of The Bends. “How Can You Be sure?” is a primarily acoustic tune featuring the sentimentality typical of Radiohead at the time.

Female backing vocals are a unique feature of the track. Credited to Diane Swann, some have suggested that the female voice is actually a band member being put through vocal effects, and the name is actually a joking reference to a “dying swan.” However, in this interview Dianne Swann confirms that she did indeed sing with Thom on this track.

songs.title: Permanent Daylight

description.plain:
According to citizeninsane.eu, this song was part of the band’s mid-1993 live set as an instrumental, and Thom explained that it had been offered for a soundtrack but ultimately rejected.

It was later released in their critically acclaimed My Iron Lung EP, released in 1994, “Permanent Daylight” is a nod to Sonic Youth, which multiple Radiohead members are fans of.

songs.title: Where Bluebirds Fly

description.plain:
These lyrics are from ‘Somewhere Over the Rainbow’ from the 1939 Wizard of Oz. The original is a beautiful song wishing of a better place.

However, this version turns the soft melodies into harsh electronic beats The somber and moaning vocals are layered on top of each other, leaving the lyrics barely understandable. It’s almost ironic, showing how life has become so much more complicated, society more pressurizing, expectations higher than ever, the way that money rules the world. An average person’s ‘over the rainbow’ utopia is very different than the one described by Judy Garland.

songs.full_title: You Never Wash Up After Yourself (Live) by Radiohead
songs.title: You Never Wash Up After Yourself (Live)
songs.title_with_featured: You Never Wash Up After Yourself (Live)

description.plain:
The seventh track on the My Iron Lung EP.

A personal song finished in just one take, this track was one of the few releases in 1994-95 that John Leckie did not help to produce. Instead, it was done with Jim Warren at the band’s makeshift Fruit Farm studio.

songs.full_title: Nude Early Band Version by Radiohead
songs.title: Nude Early Band Version

description.plain: A demo recording of ‘Nude’, for a while Radiohead’s most famous unreleased song. The song was written and seriously considered for OK Computer, but the band couldn’t produce a recording they were happy with. The song made its live debut in Japan in 1998, and would occasionally pop up during the Kid A, Amnesiac, and Hail to the Thief tours. A new version was released in 2007 on In Rainbows.
